data.name: Find Parallel Perfect Fifths
data.description:
This is a slightly more difficult variation of [Find Parallel Octaves](https://www.codewars.com/kata/62dabb2225ea8e00293da513) . If you find this Kata too difficult I recommended you start by solving that one.


You've sent your students home with an assignment for the weekend. Each student must compose a 4 part harmony consisting of *at least* 4 chords.

On Monday the four parts will be sung by a bass, tenor, alto and soprano. 

The first note in each chord will be sung by the bass, the second by the tenor, the third by the alto, and the fourth by the soprano. 

For this assignment a chord may consist of any 4 notes from the major scale.

The major scale has 7 notes:
```"do re mi fa sol la ti"```

Example:

chordOne = ```'do re fa sol'```


Each ```harmony``` consists of a number of chords:

```
harmony = [
  'mi re mi fa' ,
  'sol fa sol do' ,
  'fa ti fa ti' ,
  'fa do fa mi' , 
  ]
  ```
  
When checking if one note is a Perfect Fifth of another we look 4 spots to the right of that note in the major scale:

```
1   2   3   4    5    6     7
do  re  mi  fa   sol  la    ti 
```

```sol``` is a perfect fifth up from ```do```

however, ```do``` is *not* a perfect fifth up from ```sol```

When considering an interval you consider the lower pitch note against the higher pitched note, not the reverse.
The Bass will always sing lower than the Tenor, the Tenor will always sing lower than the Alto, and the Alto will always sing Lower than the Soprano. 



The scale is cyclical so when looking for a fifth up from ```sol```, for example. It wraps back around to ```re```

```ti``` is a perfect fiftth up from ```mi```,  and so on...



A Parallel Perfect Fifth occurs when any two singers *move* from one chord to the next while staying an interval of a Perfect Fifth apart. 

For example:
```harmony = [
'do re mi sol`
'mi sol re ti'
```

This harmony contains a Parallel Perfect Fifth. Because the Bass and Soprano are singing a Perfect Fifth apart on the first chord (```do``` and ```sol```) and when they *move* from chord 1 to chord 2 they maintain that distance of a Perfect Fifth and land on (```mi``` and ```ti```)


Another Example: 

```
harmony = [
'do re la do`
'ti re la ti'

```

In the above example; Though the Tenor and Alto are singing a Perfect Fifth apart on both the first and second chord (```re``` and ```la```) they did not *move* notes from one chord to the next. Therefor, this harmony does not contain any *Parallel* Perfect Fifths.

```
harmony = [
'ti fa la do`
'la mi la ti'

```

This harmony does not contain any Parallel Perfect Fifths. 

In the major scale the distance between the 7th degree ( ```ti```) and the 4th degree (```fa```) is a fifth, however it is a diminished fifth, not a *perfect* fifth. Therefor, it should be ignored when looking for Parallel Perfect Fifths. ```ti``` to ```fa``` is the only case in which the interval is a fifth and not a *Perfect* Fifth. 


Some of your students are over-zealous and will no doubt spend all weekend writing their harmony and will hand in assignments containing an absurd amount of chords. 
(99 of your students will turn in harmonies around 1000 to 50,000 chords long)


To save time, you would like to write a function that takes an argument ```harmony``` and returns ```'Pass'``` if the harmony does not contain any Parallel Perfect Fifths, and ```Fail``` if it does.
